text.p: (Compiled for Reuters by Media Monitors)
THE AUSTRALIAN FINANCIAL REVIEW

In a heated parliamentary sitting yesterday, Industry Minister John Moore was grilled about A$100,000 worth of shares in venture capital and management company Bligh Ventures Ltd. Moore defended his stake in the company, claiming he had ben seeking to sell his interest since May. Page 3.

Solomon Lew's Voyager Distributing Co has been drawn into a complicated legal situation sparked by a sexual harassment complaint by a deckhand who alleged he was sexually assaulted twice on the motor yacht Texas, which was used by Lew. Page 5.

Cabinet is expected to soon consider a proposal to establish a "transmission" right, which will give record companies and film production companies who currently face the widespread piracy of their content, control over the use of their material on the Internet and by cable-television operators. Page 5.

Victorian lift construction and maintenance workers have rejected a A$6.15 pay offer from elevator companies for a tax on award travel allowances, which was hoped would end the strike which has grounded the lift industry. The deal was rejected because the big firms are demanding offsets in return for the final component of the pay rise. Page 5.
THE AUSTRALIAN

Just one day after Jim Short's resignation from the Howard Ministry, Prime Minister John Howard was forced yesterday to defend Industry Minister John Moore against charges of breaching the ministerial code of conduct by still holding shares in a venture capital company valued at more than A$100,000. Page 1.

Unique authenticated dinosaur fossilised footprints - the only evidence that the tsegosaurus existed in this country - have been stolen from an Aboriginal sacred site north of Broome in Western Australia by thieves who used power tools to cut the footprints out of the rock. Page 1.

The President of the Senate, Margaret Reid, is threatening an embarrassing snub to the United States President Bill Clinton by opposing plans for him to address a historic joint sitting of Parliament - an event scheduled to be the highlight of his Australian visit in November - saying it is not "our custom" for visiting leaders to address a joint sitting. Page 1.

The Victorian Coroner's Court was told yesterday the man suspected of lighting the Kew Cottages fire in April, in which nine intellectually disabled men died, was a resident, identified only as Paul, who was known to staff as a firebug and who was seen just before and after the blaze with a cigarette lighter. Page 3.
THE SYDNEY MORNING HERALD

Just 24 hours after Assistant Treasurer Jim Short resigned, Industry, Science and Tourism Minister John Moore has been drawn into the controversy over ministerial standards after revealing yesterday he had not sold stock in Bligh Ventures Pty Ltd, an investment company he founded, because he could not get a satisfactory price. Page 1.

Under proposed new laws expected to attract bipartisan support in the Parliament, New South Wales police would gain the power to detain and interrogate suspects for up to 12 hours without laying charges - a suggestion that has enraged the legal fraternity. The New South Wales Bar Association has expressed fears that police will abuse the laws and detain people without reasonable grounds. Page 1.

Despite receiving a letter from Opposition Leader Kim Beazley yesterday seeking support for a motion backing recent comments by Governor-General Sir William Deane on the plight of Aborigines, Prime Minister John Howard has refused to commit himself to a bipartisan statement rejecting discrimination and racial intolerance. Page 3.

Controversial Independent MP Pauline Hanson, who Aboriginal leaders have been pressuring since the March election to conduct talks with an Aboriginal community, yesterday met four indigenous leaders on Queensland's Palm Island with Aboriginal activist Charles Perkins and a crew from the 60 Minutes programme. Page 3.
THE AGE

The Victorian Racing Club last night announced a review of drug testing after the Lee Freedman-trained three-year-old colt Encosta de Lago was allowed to race to victory in the A$175,000 Bill Stutt Stakes on 29 September, even though it had returned an illegal blood reading. The horse produced a reading of 37.4 - above the legal limit of 37.0 - when tested for a performance enhancing substance known as TCO2, but was still allowed to race after a highly unusual third test was conducted. Page A1.

The Coroner's Court heard yesterday that although night staff working at Kew Cottages told fire officers there was no fire, the Metropolitan Fire Brigade arrived at the scene five minutes later to discover an "extensive" fire in progress, which led to the death of nine intellectually disabled men and partially destroyed units 30 and 31 of the state institution for the intellectually disabled. Page A1.

The future of the Senate committee investigating the tendering process for the Melbourne casino is in doubt, after legal advice indicated the Commonwealth did not have the power to force state officials to give evidence. One of the two independents in the upper house has already voted with the Coalition against the inquiry. Page A1.

A 23-year-old Melbourne man, Steve Outtrim, who started out with $20 and a home computer, now has a personal fortune worth A$90 million following the spectacular debut of his company Sausage Software on the Australian Stock Exchange yesterday. The company owes its success to a best-selling computer package, Hot Dog, which helps people make better use of the Internet. Page A1.
-- Reuters Sydney Newsroom 61-2 373-1800
